message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest pyloric stenosis, which is caused by hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle. The other options listed are not associated with pyloric stenosis. The mother’s erythromycin use is a risk factor for pyloric stenosis in the newborn.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest pyloric stenosis, which is caused by hypertrophy of the smooth muscle of the pylorus. The other options are not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest pyloric stenosis, which is caused by hypertrophy of smooth muscle in the pylorus. None of the other options are associated with pyloric stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing signs of pyloric stenosis. Erythromycin use during pregnancy has not been shown to cause this disorder but it is commonly associated with firstborn males. Pyloric stenosis is caused by hypertrophy of the pyloric smooth muscle. Option B is not a known mechanism for this disorder. Option C describes mechanisms related to neural crest cell migration failure, which is associated with Hirschsprung disease. Option D describes pancreatic fusion abnormalities, which are not related to pyloric stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest pyloric stenosis, which is caused by hypertrophy of the smooth muscle of the pylorus. Intestinal vascular accident would cause bowel ischemia, neural crest cell migration failure would cause Hirschsprung disease, and pancreatic fusion abnormality would cause pancreas divisum.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of erythromycin use in the third trimester raises suspicion of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which is characterized by hypertrophy of the smooth muscle of the pylorus. The palpable mass in the epigastrum is also suggestive of this diagnosis. Intestinal vascular accidents, neural crest cell migration failure, and pancreatic fusion abnormality are not associated with this disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest hypertrophy of the pylorus, leading to pyloric stenosis. This condition occurs due to hypertrophy of smooth muscle in the wall of the pylorus. The other options listed are not related to pyloric stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including non-bilious projectile vomiting and a palpable mass in the epigastrum, suggest pyloric stenosis. This is caused by hypertrophy of the smooth muscle of the pylorus. The mother’s erythromycin use is a risk factor for pyloric stenosis. Intestinal vascular accident, neural crest cell migration failure, and pancreatic fusion abnormality are not associated with pyloric stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and age suggest pyloric stenosis. The maternal erythromycin use is a known risk factor for pyloric stenosis. Pyloric stenosis is due to hypertrophy of the smooth muscle of the pylorus. Therefore, choice (A) is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and palpable mass in the epigastrum suggest pyloric stenosis, which is caused by hypertrophy of smooth muscle in the pylorus. The other options are not associated with this condition. The mother’s use of erythromycin late in pregnancy is a risk factor for pyloric stenosis.
